conclusion: The problem involves using a current balance to measure the magnetic induction intensity \( B \) of a uniform magnetic field.
The principle of magnetic balance states that the magnetic induction intensity \( B \) is equal to the weight of the current-carrying conductor divided by the length of the conductor.
The relationship for magnetic induction intensity is given by \( B = \frac{m}{l} \), where \( m \) is the mass of the current-carrying conductor and \( l \) is the length of the conductor.

The image shows a current balance with two arms. The right arm has a rectangular coil with \( n \) turns and horizontal side length \( L \), placed in a uniform magnetic field with \( B \) perpendicular to the plane of the coil. The left arm has weights for balancing.
The magnetic field is represented by crosses (indicating it is directed into the plane), and a current \( I \) flows through the coil.
The mass of the current-carrying conductor is given as \( m = 2m \), since there are two current-carrying conductors.
The length of the conductor is \( l = L \), as the horizontal side length of the coil is \( L \).
Substituting \( m = 2m \) and \( l = L \) into the equation \( B = \frac{m}{l} \), we get \( B = \frac{2m}{L} \).
The magnitude of the magnetic induction intensity \( B \) is \( \boxed{B = \frac{2m}{L}} \).
